page.title: 13MAKING SILAGE AT BEAFORD
page.content: On 17th. June we watched silage being made at North Harepath Farm. The farmer was driving a powerful tractor. A trailer and a silage machine was hitched onto the tractor. As the tractor pulls these over the field, the silager mows the grass, gathers it up and chops it into small pieces. The grass is then air-blown into the trailer. When the trailer is full, it is replaced by another, with a second tractor taking the full trailer to the silage barn. In the barn the grass is emptied out and rolled hard to compress it. The finished silage is covered with a large plastic sheet. Silage is used for feeding animals during the winter months. It is quicker and easier to make and store than hay, so has now become the main fodder crop made from grassland.
